awd_titl_txt: QLC: EAGER: Molecular harvesting of ultrastrong light-matter coupling
awd_abstract_narration:
Joel Yuen Zhou of the University of California, San Diego, is supported by an EAGER award in the Division of Chemistry to study exotic forms of matter that arise from ultra-strong coupling between molecules and light in an optical cavity. An optical cavity is an arrangement of mirrors that forms a standing wave cavity resonator for light waves.  When ensembles of molecules are placed between closely spaced mirrors, the energy states of the molecules mix with those of the cavity photons (light particles) to produce new hybrid excited quantum states.  These states are partially molecular and partially photonic. If the energy of interaction between light and matter is sufficiently strong, an unusual phase of matter called the ultrastrong coupling (USC) phase is achieved.  In this phase, the ground state of the composite system contains a macroscopic number of photons. USC has just been successfully attained in the context of molecules embedded in optical microcavities at room temperature. What are the physicochemical properties of these exotic molecular-photonic systems?  Yuen and coworkers use theoretical approaches to address this question.   They study the onset of this phase transition as a function of system parameters that can be externally tuned.  Such parameters may be   temperature, molecular concentration or other quantities.  They will explore how USC affects chemical reactivity as well as energy conversion and storage.  The Yuen-Zhou group engages in outreach activities aimed at broadening the participation of under-represented groups in 

Yuen Zhou and his research group pioneer the theoretical and computational frameworks to understand the physics and chemistry of molecular USC between confined light and molecular degrees of freedom. In these systems, the molecular ground state in principle stores a nontrivial number of photons that can even scale with system size if the light-matter coupling is stronger than a critical threshold. Currently, there is little understanding on how to extract or use this energy. This research addresses how to harness electronic and vibrational degrees of freedom in molecules to store and release this vacuum energy and in doing so, concomitantly achieve new flavors of chemical reactivity. This project  also provides novel strategies to probe the quantum nature of the modified vacuum and explore quantum phase transitions using molecular systems. The relevance of this project is that it addresses a timely yet largely unexplored frontier at the intersection of quantum electrodynamics and chemistry.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
When molecules are placed in confined electromagnetic fields, strong coupling ensues between molecular transitions and photonic modes. This strong coupling gives rise to hybrid light-matter states known as polaritons. In the past decade, there has been much activity on how to use polaritons to control chemical change. Support from NSF through this project has enabled important theoretical investigations along this line.

  1. Our group has developed new quantum many-body methods to solve for photoinduced polaritonic dynamics associated with organic photophysical processes of technological relevance, such as triplet harvesting, which is a process of paramount important in organic light-emitting diodes (LEDs). These computational methods are a nontrivial development as they involve the accurate treatment of a large number of electrons, vibrations, and photonic degrees of freedom. From a phenomenological standpoint, we have elucidated the conditions under which LEDs could benefit from polaritons, in the regime of one to hundreds of molecules per photon mode [see: J. Chem. Phys. 151, 054106 (2019); Sci. Adv. 5, 12, eaax4482 (2019)].
  2. We have put forward the first theoretical proposal of a molecular version of the dynamical Casimir effect (DCE). In the standard version of this effect, a prohibitively fast modulation of the quantum vacuum gives rise to the production of photon pairs, in a way that is very much analogous to the production of Hawking radiation. This phenomenon is fundamentally important because it shows inherently quantum mechanical properties of the electromagnetic vacuum. In our proposal, we suggest that molecules that photoisomerize and are strongly coupled to nanoconfined plasmonic media give rise to a DCE that occurs in the natural ultrafast timescales of the molecular photoisomerization, hence ameliorating the conditions for the observation of the DCE [see J. Phys. Chem. Lett. 11, 1, 152 (2020)].
  3. In recent years, experiments have shown that strong coupling between vibrational modes of molecules and infrared optical cavities can give rise to control of chemical kinetics even in the absence of optical pumping. This puzzling result is technologically important because one could conceive turning reactions on and off by simply placing molecular samples inside of the correct cavity. Hence, this type of cavity-controlled reactions can in-principle become a game changer in the chemical industry, allowing one to bypass costly and time-consuming synthetic modifications. We provided the so-far only theory that can possibly explain this result in the collective regime, where experiments are carried out [see ACS Cent. Sci. 5, 3, 386 (2019); Nat. Commun. 10, 4685 (2019)].
  4. A simple and tunable way to control the outcome of photochemical and photophysical processes is by engineering the optical density of states of the surrounding environment. Together with our experimental colleagues, we have demonstrated this approach by suppressing energy transfer between donor-acceptor pairs of molecules utilizing arrays of plasmonic nanoparticles [see ACS Photonics 8, 2211 (2021)].

In summary, support from this NSF QLC: EAGER grant has provided important foundations for the emerging field of polariton chemistry, where state-of-the-art optical elements are deployed to control chemical processes and properties. This field is interesting from a fundamental standpoint in that it merges cavity quantum-electrodynamics with physical chemistry, leading to interesting regimes of collective chemical dynamics. From a broader standpoint, research developed in this project paves the way to a possibly new generation of chemical synthesis procedures that exploit optical cavities and the broader contemporary photonics toolbox.
